articles.headline: Inflation and Stocks Are Both Up, and That’s Stirring Some Worries
articles.snippet: It’s long been believed that inflation and higher interest rates are bad for stock prices. Now, it’s unclear how the markets will react.
articles.abstract: It’s long been believed that inflation and higher interest rates are bad for stock prices. Now, it’s unclear how the markets will react.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, fears of higher-than-expected inflation and interest rates sent stocks into a historic and nerve-rattling plunge. This week, those fears were borne out: Consumer prices rose more than expected in January, and interest rates jumped.

articles.headline: Senate Rejects Immigration Plans, Leaving Fate of Dreamers Uncertain
articles.snippet: Three measures — including one backed by President Trump — failed to garner the 60 votes required to open Senate debate. The next steps are unclear.
articles.abstract: Three measures — including one backed by President Trump — failed to garner the 60 votes required to open Senate debate. The next steps are unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate summarily blocked three measures on Thursday — including one backed by President Trump — to resolve the fate of the so-called Dreamers, leaving hundreds of thousands of them facing an uncertain future.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: A Mother Weeps for Her Angel: ‘I Hope She Didn’t Die for Nothing’
articles.snippet: As students who survived the Florida school massacre struggled to make sense of the horror and loss, an entire community turns out at a vigil.
articles.abstract: As students who survived the Florida school massacre struggled to make sense of the horror and loss, an entire community turns out at a vigil.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARKLAND, Fla. — For the latest on the Florida school shooting, read Friday’s live updates.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Audra D. S. Burch and Liam Stack

articles.headline: Nikolas Cruz, Florida Shooting Suspect, Showed ‘Every Red Flag’
articles.snippet: Mr. Cruz, the suspect in the Parkland, Fla., school shooting, had no criminal history. But his childhood was certainly difficult.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cruz, the suspect in the Parkland, Fla., school shooting, had no criminal history. But his childhood was certainly difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARKLAND, Fla. — Before he was hauled into a jailhouse hearing room on Thursday, head bowed and shackled at the wrists and ankles, Nikolas Cruz had been causing trouble as long as anyone here could remember.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Gunfire Erupts at a School. Leaders Offer Prayers. Children Are Buried. Repeat.
articles.snippet: Deadly shootings in schools have become a sad and distinct American ritual, with familiar images and a familiar response.
articles.abstract: Deadly shootings in schools have become a sad and distinct American ritual, with familiar images and a familiar response.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the latest on the Florida school shooting, read Friday’s live updates.

articles.headline: ‘Black Panther’ Poised to Shatter a Hollywood Myth
articles.snippet: The film is expected to take in at least $250 million worldwide this weekend, disproving the notion that movies rooted in black culture cannot be global blockbusters.
articles.abstract: The film is expected to take in at least $250 million worldwide this weekend, disproving the notion that movies rooted in black culture cannot be global blockbusters.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ticket buyers around the world are poised to smash another one of Hollywood’s most entrenched beliefs.

articles.headline: Children’s Book Industry Has Its #MeToo Moment
articles.snippet: Allegations of mistreatment of women flooded the children’s publishing industry over the past week and ensnared James Dashner, the author of the “Maze Runner” series.
articles.abstract: Allegations of mistreatment of women flooded the children’s publishing industry over the past week and ensnared James Dashner, the author of the “Maze Runner” series.
articles.lead_paragraph: The week began with the world of children’s and young adult literature celebrating its most prestigious awards, the industry’s version of the Oscars. It ended with surprise and confusion as trade groups, literary agents and a publisher broke with several best-selling authors over allegations of inappropriate sexual behavior.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Don’t Like Your Mortgage Servicer? Good Luck Trying to Switch
articles.snippet: Borrowers can’t simply cut off a lender or servicer like Wells Fargo. Sound familiar? Retirement plans and student lending are like this, too.
articles.abstract: Borrowers can’t simply cut off a lender or servicer like Wells Fargo. Sound familiar? Retirement plans and student lending are like this, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Any one of the sins that Wells Fargo committed against consumers would have been bad enough.
